results.title: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit glass slides (Reptiles)
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description: There are three parts to the Reptiles slides, each slide has 4 images. These small slides have red sealing tape around the edges. These slides form part of The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit with removable chimney and internal wooden block. The lantern is housed in original box with metal handle, and internal red and blue graphic for: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit. 20 glass slides in custom box, length of textile to keep box shut, 2 small empty boxes which act to store slides in a snug manner.

results.title: Spotlights: Bruna Papandrea
results.brief_description: Bruna Papandrea is an Australian film and television producer and the founder of production company Made Up Stories, which released the adaptation of Liane Moriarty’s Nine Perfect Strangers in 2021.
results.description: Bruna Papandrea is an Australian film and television producer and the founder of production company Made Up Stories, which released the adaptation of Liane Moriarty’s Nine Perfect Strangers in 2021. Prior to Made Up Stories, Papandrea co-founded the production company, Pacific Standard, with Reese Witherspoon, which produced Gone Girl and Big Little Lies.
description_for_label: Bruna Papandrea is an Australian film and television producer and the founder of production company Made Up Stories, which released the adaptation of Liane Moriarty’s Nine Perfect Strangers in 2021. Prior to Made Up Stories, Papandrea co-founded the production company, Pacific Standard, with Reese Witherspoon, which produced Gone Girl and Big Little Lies.

results.title: Rodeo Baby!
results.brief_description:
“The artwork is centred upon the belief that it is our own bodies that are the truest archive of our experience and that any documentation is only ever an approximation of the person doing the gazing – not the gazed.”

While trawling archival video material, Jazz Money discovered an overwhelming amount of footage of First Peoples in rodeos. There was the joy of seeing Blak faces, but an unease in knowing non-Indigenous voyeurs likely captured the footage. In the vast network of archives in this country’s institutions, photos and videos of First Peoples are filed away, with the people who have been recorded – often unknowingly – and their descendants unaware the recordings exist.

Jazz reclaims these images, combining them with stills from film and TV, including “The Phantom Stockman” (1953), “Radiance” (1998) and” The Drover’s Wife” (2021), in this large-scale photographic essay. It celebrates First Peoples representation and the Aboriginal scholars who critique this colonial hoarding, giving new meaning to images that have been dislocated by archival practices. Jazz asks, “If these archival collections are the rodeo, who is playing cowboy with our images?”

constellations_primary.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_primary.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: Extraction
constellations_other.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences
